comments.text:
+beepIL
War can be just. St.Augustine discussed this quite heavily, and although me 
and him disagree on what constitutes a just war, I do wholeheartedly 
believe the concept is true (as true as true gets lol).

Also, the point is to turn the majority side to the ethical, so that way in 
dictating war, public policy, social spending etc., we are able to do so 
efficiently and also with respect to the lives that will be affected by 
such decisions. I also understand very well that the Israeli army isn't 
comprised completely of murderous lunatics (I have seen videos of them fire 
on civilians though, but one bad apple is not the entire case), but I don't 
believe the government there to be very just, at the top levels.

Damn near no government is. I would just as easily shit on the governments 
of Iran, the US, China, France and any other nation for doing similar 
things and I have repeatedly. Mostly the US because I live here, and news 
on the government is easily obtained. Do I think China did the right shit 
in Hong Kong regarding how they handled the protests? Fuck no.

I would murder thousands of 100% DNA evidenced, murder weapon known, 
witness etc. of mass murderers, and I would just as easily get rid of those 
who are fucking 13 year olds and younger regularly. There is people that 
*NEED* to go, but sadly enough they are everywhere and for some reason they 
seem to coagulate on the top levels of governments. Not to say there hasn't 
been legitimately trying hard, good honest leaders... just they seem to get 
killed pretty young often times, and even those that were maybe half-assed 
decent people still get murked :( . What these people need to do is fight 
back. Wage your own war against the bigots, extremists, and intolerant 
fucks. A jihad against all around disrespect to what it means to be alive.

That would be the spiritual war I would be down to join... but that's why 
you spread the word and speak to as many people as you can. So slowly the 
level of critical thinking goes up... it's a change we *need* to make if 
we're to make it as a species with the ability to annihilate damn near all 
the planets in the solar system (We have thousands upon thousands of 
nuclear warheads on the planet), and soon be able to build super power 
lasers powered by fusion reactors. I'm not down for thoughtless violence, 
but if comes to violence I will stand tall and take whatever's coming 
hopefully and Dish out the best that I can if I am to die for something I 
believe in. I hope it never comes to that, hence why I speak first. Fuck 
all that needless bullshit filling up the little smidgen of time I have in 
this universe. I got shit to do :)
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime not argumentative at all mate, we are just having a 
conversation :)
Your attitude is healthy, but on the battlefield it doesn't change a thing,
when one side can seize an advantage by being anything but honorable for 
the benefit of winning, that side will do just that... and if the other 
side wont do it as well, then they are as good as dead, its human nature, 
its the same reason why communism cant really work, for these things to 
work everyone must work in the same manner, and it takes no more than a few 
to go against the current to break the whole system down, and this is true 
for war as well, this is why (and sorry to say this) as much you want it, 
and as hard as you will try, there will never be enough people who act this 
way, and there will always be those who do the opposite if it, and as long 
as such people exist, it is a fiction.

if you want to compare it on ethics, then you may be happy to hear that 
compared with history to this day we are actually very ethical in our 
conduct of war...
Israel and the palestinians were discussed here, with all the rant and 
criticism towards israel, it is still an army that drops leaflets warning 
civilians beforehand to evacuate as they happen to sit on an ammo dump etc, 
it is still the army which its soldiers will NOT open fire on civilians for 
"the heck of it" and will shoot only at combatants (collateral damage and 
accidents do happen, and in war civilian casualties will always occur, 
intentional or otherwise)
compare it to one of the armies of ancient times... hell, they would go 
door to door and behead anyone in their path with no regards for human life,
we are becoming better, but as much as you strive to be better, you need to 
understand that as some point you will hit a barrier, its the point you 
will realize that to reach this level of ethics there can be no war,
you cant have an ethical war, war in itself is an unethical act committed 
by two groups against one another, there is nothing ethical about killing 
others,and that is why you cant have ethical warriors and ethical wars,
sure today (in some parts of the world at least) soldiers wont go and rape 
civilians , but it wont make the task of killing others by the bulk any 
more ethical.
comments.author: beepIL

comments.text:
+beepIL
I've had to rewrite this comment three fucking times... urgggghh. My comp 
kept on crashing, had to do a system restore :P. I'm not trying to be 
argumentative btw, I would hope that you feel the same way.

Anyways, I understand all the cultures I listed quite well. I also 
understand no culture is perfect, it's more a journey towards perfection 
(like life itself). But in this journey we can take what was right and 
leave the rest, and grow from knowing the histories of the people whom came 
before us; and not disregard their wisdom along with their faults.

Also, yes; I would rather have people joining the army knowing they may end 
up cannon fodder and doing so honorably, as opposed to coming to the 
conclusion that killing is the only thing that matters and as long as 
you're alive; fuck the rest. This would serve as a barrier to war as well, 
because the human costs would be much higher, and I think we could do well 
with a reminder of what war is really costing us as a people. Namely 
people...

The only way we change reality is to change the way we think about reality. 
DMX "It doesn't have to be the way it is, just because the past twenty 
years everyday it is". There's a huge lesson to be learned in these lyrics. 
That is not the attitude of a defeatist, which is what I'm sensing coming 
from you when you talk about ethics and moral philosophy. The more people 
talk about it and implement it in their everyday personal lives, the closer 
we come to the reality of which you call a fiction. I would gladly die to 
spread this word, and I would be willing to fight tooth and nail for this 
as well; if it ever came to that. I understand violence well, I also 
understand it's price; that's what living in a violent environment will do 
to you... hence the code of honor I have set among myself regarding it.

I hope one day people like you will preach the message of ethics and 
beneficial change as quickly as you have been to denounce it as a fairy 
tale, because honestly... "we" could use every damned on of you in the 
fight to make this world a forward thinking and more equitable place for 
all. None of the societal changes you hold so dear would've became a 
reality with a defeatist attitude. I understand that my goal may not be met 
in my lifetime... but that's not the purpose. The purpose is to make it 
better for the ones coming long after us, this shit is a lot bigger than 
you or me ya know?
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime The samurai? you know very little about them then, their 
honor was well mixed with raping and drinking like useless brutes, and the 
spartans? who enslaved another people to do their non combat related tasks 
so they can live like kings and focus only on warfare? was that also 
honorable?
and knights? do you think most knights gave two shits about their code? 
most of them were no better than the average samurai, raping, killing and 
looting, just look at the crusades, they even raped and looted christians 
on their march to the middle east. you are obviously influenced by 
romanticized literature, which is very far from what reality was, but dont 
take my word for it... research these things yourself.

I agree that we should control and distance ourselves from the efficient 
killer nature that we have in ourselves, but for that to work, both sides 
need to conduct themselves this way... if only one side will, that side 
will lose.

look at how many pointless lives were lost in the name of proper 
"honorable" battle lines in the victorian era,
so is that better? being honorable and less an efficient killer? in combat 
you want to be nothing short of as efficient a killer as you can be, 
anything less will put your own life at risk, as well as cost you the 
combat \ war.

dont dream up honor and codes, war never truly had them, since ancient 
history to this day, in reality, its kill or be killed, and you better be 
more scary, stronger and more efficient in doing so... anything else is 
rubbish, and history is there time and time again to prove this point.

dont get me wrong, i would love to have this fictional reality where 
warriors were really honorable by the bulk as you said, rather than having 
very isolated examples of such cases, and that people would be more 
honorable in their warfare conduct, but reality just isn't like this... 
sorry.

just imagine the scenario of "brothers in arms" you see your friends die in 
front of you, people you love, you think you will really have any honor and 
respect for those who killed them? you cant pit two groups of people in a 
goal to kill one another and expect honor to blossom from it, war is hell, 
that statement was not said in vain.
comments.author: beepIL

comments.text:
+beepIL
The ideals behind ethics only become fiction when we make them just that by 
denying them and further falling away from them. If you wanted real change 
in this world you really should attack the paradigm of thought that allows 
humans to waste life dishonorably and in a fashion that makes us the most 
brutally efficient murders known on the entire planet. The rest of your 
point is a continuation of what was said in the first two sentences so I 
think that covers it.

And yes, there has been warriors who fought with honor. The Samurai, 
Spartans, the Royal British Army (in the Romantic/Victorian era, and please 
note I didn't mention the navy), and the knights of the past. All these 
people conducted themselves with at least a standard of decency and 
discipline that modern day men could use to learn in their everyday 
interactions.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+Dan -
I didn't compare the two, I simply said that criticism is necessary at all 
times. You were coming close to making the claim might makes right. That is 
a scary slope to slide down; this was all I was trying to avoid.

I'm not saying they need to imediately give up all of their territories. 
There is never an all or nothing solution. Secondly I never said I agree 
with how Hamas or the PLO conduct themselves, but returning to the 1967 
borders would be a good goal to move towards slowly but surely.

Nobody gave a shit when Israel vacated thousands from their homes, why 
would they expect the same people they made refugees to respect their 
claims in their own homeland? Secondly, is the terrorist the one who is 
fighting to gain back land that was wrongfully taken from him; or the one 
who stole the land and is using modern military technology against an 
opponent who often times still throws rocks and uses homemade pipe bombs? 
Really matters who's doing the calling out doesn't it?
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime I still fail to see constructive criticism, just so you know 
the only country that did sign the Geneva convention in this whole mess is 
Israel, furthermore the Geneva convention regards mostly war conducted 
between countries that have established militias, not terrorists or 
"Freedom fighters" which are technically qualified as civilians.

You are however right that power does not make one right, however I fail to 
see how the Hamas or PLO or whatever other "Freedom Fighting Organization" 
has any legitimate or even remotely okayish argument for what their doing. 
Most of the Palestinians hate them so they're not representing anyone, and 
they're doing nothing to establish peace. 

They are however very proficient at making unrealistic demands, like 
demanding we go back to the 67 borders, which would mean vacating hundreds 
of thousands of people and leaving Israel at a measly 9 KM width at its 
center. Not to mention they have no claim to the 67 borders, we won them in 
a war. Russia isn't giving away any of its territory to the Japanese and 
neither is America to its natives. Just because those wars happened earlier 
doesn't suddenly mean that they were times at which it was okay to take 
land but now its bad.

Also I just can't believe someone would steep as low as comparing Israel to 
the USSR or the Nazis, it's fucking disgusting. Israel is treating its 
enemies better than some of its enemies treat their own fucking people. 
Watch some "Israeli violence against Palestinians" videos, I am sure in 
every video you'll see some obnoxious Palestinians shoving their faces and 
flags into soldier's faces and all they get tops is arrested, if they 
really cross the line. I'd like to see a Jew waving a Bible into a Nazi's 
face and measly getting arrested.
comments.author: Dan -

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime what war conducted itself within the restrictions of geneva 
conventions? USA in iraq? what war was fought with respect to the geneva 
conventions since these conventions were established?
the geneva conventions are a fiction, much like the UN...
what did the UN ever do to prevent or change anything REAL on the field? 
other thank empty talks in a big hall?
all of these things are nothing more than the natural reaction of a 
traumatized world post WW2, something that exists so the west can tell 
itself that it changed its ways and that horrible things like WW2 would not 
repeat...
what conventions and honor is there in two groups of people killing each 
other? do you think that in the heat of battle anyone gives a crap about 
conventions made in Geneva and what the UN says you can or cannot do? 
have you ever been to a war? did you fight in one and experienced combat? i 
dont talk about calm engagements from kilometers away, i am talking about 
fierce fighting from house to house in desperate odds, do you think you 
would give a flipping fuck for conventions? you wont... no one will, and 
its nothing but nativity talking if you think they matter.
comments.author: beepIL

comments.text:
+Dan -
Dan... I don't hate you, but I hate your point of view. Might *DOES NOT* 
make right. If you believe that, then that means the Nazis, the Red Russian 
army, the soldiers at Abu Ghraib, and the Japanese Imperial army were 
justified in their war crimes and if that type of criticism is empty to 
you; than we can no longer have a constructive conversation.

No where did I say all Israeli's are scum. Nowhere did I say the country 
has never provided anything of use, but just like the other regimes I 
mentioned; they too had provided many new technologies and military 
advancements that were further implemented in the civilian world. Does that 
now mean they are free of criticisms of their bad behavior?

And furthermore, *YES* there is an appropriate reaction in war. That's why 
we have the Geneva Conventions and the rules of war. It's how *supposedly* 
civilized nation are supposed to conduct themselves in the face of horror. 
If you also do not agree with that, then we shouldn't talk after this point.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:

you saying we should have just killed a Palestinian every time an Israeli

every Arab in the nearest facility if it had wanted to because they are

supplying electricity, food, medicine, building materials (which the Arabs 
use to build tunnels for terrorist purposes) and etc.

This empty criticism is kind of annoying me, could you give me an example 
of what Israel could have done better in the war? How Israel should act? 
Because all I see now is you proposing that Israel, a nation with so much 
more power than the shits that surround it should succumb to their demands 
because of: Reasons!
comments.author: Dan -

I know the PLO was for it at a time. I know that Hamas has turned it down

comments.text:
+beepIL
Dude, I could honestly give a fuck less about international law; but I'm 
pretty sure treating the Palestinian people as if they deserve less and 
less room to live in land that was just as much theirs as any of yours is 
pretty much what genocide is, and I am also pretty sure that is against 
international law. Look at the territories on a map from 1948 till now. 
Tell me if that were an animal what would you call it... I'll let you know, 
endangered. Endangering an entire ethnicity is genocide, whether or not the 
"security" counsel agrees or not.

Frankly that UN vote was *SHIT* and the "security" counsel is an utter shit 
idea as well, look what it created: A nation that robs citizens of *MY* 
homeland and *MY* hard earned money, without their full consent by the 
*BILLIONS*, agrees to one things then goes back on it again and again (the 
territories), and continues to cause *far more* massive casualties than it 
receives: Also, if you wanna get real, the torah doesn't even allow the 
Jews to have a homeland until the second coming, which obviously wasn't 
fulfilled by Jesus; as the Jews do not believe that Jesus was the savior.

I do not think your whole nation consists of Right-Wing extremists, I think 
your government does. I don't think you are a horrible person, I think as a 
group your nation is; as mine is, and I don't hate anyone... I would just 
rather have seen legitimate means to forge a new nation, rather than mass 
agreed upon theft and thereafter denied atrocities. Remember at one time 
the world agreed upon slavery as well.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

top_comment.text:
So why is Hank pronouncing methanethiol "METH-uhn-ETH-ee-ol" and not like 
two the two separate words that it derives its name from "METH-ane-THI-ol"? 
I am a chemist and have never heard it pronounced that way before, and I 
would assume that with Hank's chem background he would know the correct 
pronunciation. So which is correct?﻿
top_comment.author: DoctorProfessorPatrick

comments.text: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It just sounds weird to me.
comments.author: DoctorProfessorPatrick

comments.text:
I've taken a good share of chemistry classes, but I'm not a chemist by any 
stretch of the word. I've always heard it pronounced the first way. I think 
we're used to pronouncing it with the short 'a' because of other words that 
do. For example, I've never heard anyone say "meth-ane-nol".

I decided to look around the Internet a little. Every audio recording 
sounds like that first, single word version. But, every written 
pronunciation sounds like "methane-thiol". The first one does roll off the 
tongue better.
comments.author: albinoman13bt

have been common sense to our ancestors to just eat the stem and not the 
flower.

top_comment.text:
Since this episode brought up Vitamin K, we need a comprehensive episode to 
explain what vitamins are, why some of the letters are skipped while B has 
so many subtypes, and how much to take.﻿
top_comment.author: Blinky Lass

comments.text:
+DXXI
 There are some wrong things there. ADEK since are fat soluble vitamins are 
mainly excreted by the liver, and that goes to feces when they are in 
excess.
Also, a vitamin is something you cannot produce and need to take up with 
your food (with the exception of vitamin D and UV from the sun, which you 
can produce limited amounts). So "Your body produces these vitamins every 
day" is simply wrong.
comments.author: Fernando Alemán

comments.text:
+DXXI Im too lazy and tired to read that now so we do need a scishow 
episode!
comments.author: the guy who never uploads anything

comments.text: +DXXI Thanks for the information. I still want it in video format though.
comments.author: Blinky Lass

comments.text:
There are two types of vitamins
the ones that are water soluble: the B-complex group such as B12,B6,B3,B2 
and folic acid (vitaminM) and vitamin C. You must only take these vitamins 
if you have a deficiency because you are not taking the right types of 
food. Most multivitamin supplements are only recommended for pregnant women 
who are experiencing health related issues. 

and the fat soluble vitamins: A,D,E and K. These are the ones you should 
worry about when talking about urine. Fat soluble vitamins go through your 
"filtration system" like the liver and the kidneys which in large 
quantities can lead to SERIOUS medical issues. Your body produces these 
vitamins every day so any excess gets excreted from your liver or your 
kidneys to waste.

As for the letters in the alphabet, a woman named Cornnelia Kennedy used A 
and B to simplify the vitamin from amino acids (amine and vital). Then Jack 
Cecil in 1920 decided that A was fat soluble and B was water soluble. We 
skipped to K because it was said that multiple vitamins were reclassified 
into the B category (for example G was reclassified to B2).
comments.author: DXXI

comments.text:
Unless you have a vitamin deficiency diagnosed by a doctor, there's no need 
to take vitamins. In the US vitamin supplements aren't regulated by the FDA 
very closely so pharmaceutical companies get away with telling you how much 
you and your child need them. In reality you're just making your pee more 
expensive, because you just urinate excess vitamins. In some cases it can 
be hurtful. Taking calcium tablets when you don't need them, even if you're 
at an age where you're expecting bone loss, can cause extremely painful 
kidney stones. Most foods are genetically modified and have tons of vitamin 
production crammed into their DNA already so usually there's no need to 
take even more. 

Still though, a sci show episode on this is a good idea.

comments.text:
You're not alone.  Like Iceman says, it's more of a philosophical issue and 
it actually has very deep implications.  The base of the question is "Can 
we trust our senses or not?"  We can validate that most humans tend to view 
the world in the same way that we do.  We can place a blue cup on our desk 
and get hundreds of people to tell us what is on the desk.  I can't imagine 
a scenario where someone would not validate that it is indeed a cup, but a 
few may be unable to validate the color.  The reason that it has such deep 
implications is this.  If what I perceive is inaccurate, then how can I 
find truth?  Is the pursuit of truth impossible if I cannot trust my senses?
comments.author: Adam Sloan

top_comment.text:
Why does it not tickle when you tickle yourself? i have always wanted to 
know that question﻿
top_comment.author: audrey zelinke

comments.text: cool thx Mary Jane
comments.author: audrey zelinke

comments.text:
Scientific American has a “Ask the Expert” series, and someone asked why it 
was impossible to tickle yourself.

*The answer lies at the back of the brain in an area called the cerebellum, 
which is involved in monitoring movements. Our studies at University 
College London have shown that the cerebellum can predict sensations when 
your own movement causes them but not when someone else does. When you try 
to tickle yourself, the cerebellum predicts the sensation and this 
prediction is used to cancel the response of other brain areas to the 
tickle.*

*Two brain regions are involved in processing how tickling feels. The 
somatosensory cortex processes touch and the anterior cingulate cortex 
processes pleasant information. We found that both these regions are less 
active during self-tickling than they are during tickling performed by 
someone else, which helps to explains why it doesn’t feel tickly and 
pleasant when you tickle yourself. Further studies using robots showed that 
the presence of a small delay between your own movement and the resulting 
tickle can make the sensation feel tickly. Indeed, the longer the delay, 
the more tickly it feels. So it might be possible to tickle yourself, if 
you are willing to invest in a couple of robots!*

Hmm, so the key here seems to be the inability to predict *what* movement 
someone is going to do to try to tickle you. Only novel sensations tickle, 
and they aren’t novel if you made them. I want to know what study used 
robots to tickle people. Cause thats just crazy.

*Unashamedly copied and pasted from scienceblog website*
comments.author: Mary Jane

comments.text: WHY HAVEN"T YOU?
comments.author: Urbarask Praetor

captions.text: [Intro]

You've probably never smelled a skunk and
wished that you could reproduce that lovely

odor with your own bodily fluids, but if you're
among a certain 40% of humans, you actually

kind of can. All you gotta do is eat some
asparagus, wait a little bit, and then pee
on your enemies.

Asparagus is a weird little vegetable, it's
a monocot, meaning that its seeds start out

with only one leaf, and it's related to onions
and garlic. Its flowers are actually poisonous

to humans, but the stems have plenty of nutrients
in them, like vitamin K and vitamin C, and

since as far back as the 1890s, scientists
have been trying to figure out why it makes

peoples' pee smell like, you know, just different,
maybe a little worse than usual. Of course,

all sorts of foods, like coffee and garlic,
can change the chemistry of your urine, which

makes sense; some foods contain strong smelling
compounds that your body can't digest completely,

and they gotta somewhere. Sometimes that somewhere
is your urine. And asparagus has its own stinky

chemical that doesn't seem to be found anywhere
else; it's called asparagusic acid, and when

it's digested, it produces sulfur compounds
like methanethiol and dimethyl sulfide. Sulfur,

of course, is famous for giving things like
skunk spray and rotten eggs their unique aromas.

But the weird thing is that for a lot of people,
eating a lot of asparagus doesn't seem to

have an effect on their excreta, it just smells
totally normal, so when scientists started

trying to figure out why that is, they figured
that there were two possible explanations.

One is that people who claimed to have non-smelly
pee were just non-excretors, that is, they

didn't produce urine with the compounds that
smell. But the other possibility was that

they were producing the compounds, but they
couldn't smell them. To get to the bottom

of the issue, in 1956, two biologists at Oxford
conducted a study in which 115 people were

fed asparagus and then they had their urine
analyzed. The results showed that some samples

did appear to smell while others didn't, and
the urine specimens that had the unique scent

all contained the same compound, methanethiol.
Since then, other studies have found even

more byproducts of asparagusic acid in excretors'
urine, like dimethyl sulfide and dimethyl

sulfone, so it seemed pretty clear that people
were either excretors or non-excretors.

But then, we kept studying it. In 1980, another
researcher, this time in Israel, began to

wonder if everyone's urine did smell after
eating asparagus, but some people just couldn't

smell it. A really astonishing amount of research
has gone into answering this question. Anyway,

he managed to get 307 people to agree to sniff
different concentrations of one person's smelly

asparagus pee. And it turns out that he was
kind of right. Some people could smell the

scent, but others who were given the same
specimen couldn't smell a thing. So. Everyone
was pretty confused for a while.

Then, in 2011, the Monell Chemical Senses
Center in Philadelphia tested both possibilities

at the same time. Their subjects gave urine
samples before and after eating asparagus,

and also had to smell different samples from
other people who had eaten asparagus. The

researchers concluded that both hypotheses
were essentially correct. It turned out that

people were either excretors or non-excretors,
and they could either be smellers or non-smellers.

So some people produce smelly urine but can't
smell it, and some people produce the smelly

urine and can smell it, I'm one of those,
and some people don't produce it but they

can detect traces of asparagus in other peoples'
pee. Scientists have gone on to determine

that all of these differences are genetic.
Non-smellers have something called a specific

anosmia, where one of their 400 or so smell-receptor
genes is mutated and effectively turned off.

That same kind of mutation is what makes some
people unable to smell things like vanilla

or mint. If you can have one of those turned
off, I'd prefer the asparagus pee one than

the vanilla one, that's just a bummer. The
non-excretors, meanwhile, have a different

genetic mutation that keeps them from excreting
the compound in the first place, but no one

is really sure where the compounds go if they
aren't excreted. So, it seems that there's

even more work to be done into the science
of asparagus pee. Maybe you'll be the one

to do it. French author Marcel Proust once
said that asparagus, "as in a Shakespeare

fairy-story transforms my chamber-pot into
a flask of perfume." We're all about curiosity

here at SciShow, so does asparagus turn your
chamber pot into perfume? Let us know.

To learn how you can help us keep exploring
pressing questions like this, you can go to

Subbable.com/SciShow, and don't forget to
go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe if

you just want to keep getting smarter and
learnin' weird stuff. Because that's what
we do here.

title: The Truth About Asparagus and Your Pee
